title: Week 1: December 29–January 4 - Introduction to the Old Testament

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, let's dive right into a mystery that's shocked readers for centuries. In John 8:58-59, Jesus says just five words: 'Before Abraham was, I am.' And the Jews immediately pick up stones to stone him. Why this explosive reaction to such a simple statement?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, those words were no accident—they were a bold claim to divinity. Jesus was directly invoking the sacred name God revealed to Moses in Exodus 3:13-15: 'I AM THAT I AM.' In Hebrew, that's YHWH, the eternal name of Jehovah. To claim 'I am' was to say, 'I am Jehovah God Himself.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's fascinating. So the Jews recognized it as blasphemy unless He truly was that God. But how does Exodus 6:3 fit in? It says God appeared to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as God Almighty, but not as Jehovah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly, it reveals a divine pattern of progressive revelation. The Joseph Smith Translation clarifies in the footnote to Exodus 6:3 that God was known to them by Jehovah but the fullness of that name wasn't fully comprehended until Moses. This sets up Jesus as the same Jehovah speaking throughout the Old Testament.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Hold on—that shifts everything. President Oaks taught that scriptural records of 'God' or 'Lord' are almost always Jehovah, our Savior Jesus Christ. So the Old Testament is filled with Christ's voice?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Precisely, Sarah. It's like peeling back layers of a mystery. Ancient Israel heard Jehovah's covenants and laws, but now we see it's pre-mortal Christ preparing His people for His mortal ministry.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that multi-perspective view: Israel's ancient encounters, Christ's own claims, and our restored understanding. But let's trace a pattern—how does knowing Jesus is Jehovah change how we read symbols that testify of Him?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here's where it gets powerful. Moses 6:63 teaches, 'All things have their likeness, and all things are created and made to bear record of me.' Look at manna in Exodus 16:4, 11-15—it's the bread from heaven, just as Jesus declares in John 6:35, 'I am the bread of life.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's remarkable! So everyday provision points to the Savior. What else stands out?

script.speaker: David
script.text: The sacrificial lamb in Exodus 12:3-5 foreshadows John 1:29: 'Behold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world.' Then Numbers 21:4-10's brass serpent lifted up heals those who look—echoed in John 3:14 as Christ's crucifixion.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And Jonah, swallowed for three days in Jonah 1:4-17, prefigures Christ's resurrection, as in Matthew 12:38-41. These aren't coincidences; they're divine patterns across dispensations.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Right, Sarah. From Adam's sacrifices bearing record of Christ, to Abraham's covenant, Moses' symbols, Christ's fulfillment, and restoration through Joseph Smith—it's a thread of redemption woven through time.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Speaking of restoration, the Lord told Nephi in 1 Nephi 13:21-29, 38-42 that plain and precious things were removed from the Bible. How does that connect to our Old Testament study?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Beautiful question. 2 Nephi 3:12 shows the Bible and Book of Mormon confirming each other. Joseph Smith restored key accounts: Enoch's Zion in Moses 7:18-19, Abraham's council in heaven in Abraham 3:22-28, and Melchizedek's ministry in JST Genesis 14:25-40.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I never connected those as 'plain and precious' restorations. Why are they so vital?

script.speaker: David
script.text: They reveal the Plan of Salvation in vivid detail—pre-mortal councils, gathering of Zion, priesthood power—all tying back to Jehovah's covenants with ancient prophets.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: This builds such anticipation. Now, let's dive into historical context. What made the name Jehovah so sacred to ancient Israel?

script.speaker: David
script.text: In ancient Near Eastern culture, knowing a god's name gave power and intimacy. Exodus 3 shows Moses at the burning bush, trembling to ask. Jehovah's response, 'I AM THAT I AM,' asserts eternal self-existence—no beginning, no end.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That cultural insight makes it immediate. No wonder Jesus' claim provoked stones. But from Israel's view, Jehovah was their covenant God.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, Exodus 19:5 calls Israel His 'peculiar treasure' through covenant. This echoes across dispensations: Abraham's posterity, Mosaic law, even Jeremiah 31:31-34's new covenant written on hearts.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Pattern emerging—covenants as Jehovah's way to gather His people. How does this resolve our opening mystery?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It culminates in Christ revealing Himself as that covenant Jehovah. The stoning attempt highlights the veil over His identity, lifted in restoration. Suddenly, the Old Testament pulses with His voice calling us to covenants.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's the resolution I needed! Now, hidden connections—what most people miss linking Psalms to these?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Psalm 119:105: 'Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.' This light motif traces to divine light in Moses, Christ's light of the world, and D&C temples.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wait, like Enoch's Zion taken to God's light in Moses 7?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly. And Abraham 3's intelligences organized under Jehovah's light. It's a Plan of Salvation pattern: from premortal light, through mortal covenants, to eternal glory.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Profound. Elder Renlund urges focusing on Jesus as the treasure. How do these symbols do that?

script.speaker: David
script.text: They transform reading: every symbol whispers Christ. Isaiah 53:3-9's suffering servant, Psalm 23's shepherd— all Jehovah leading to Atonement.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Isaiah 7:14 and 9:6 foretell the virgin birth and Prince of Peace. Even children can see baby Jesus there.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And covenants for children: baptism like Mosiah 18:10, temple promises. President Nelson's 'The Everlasting Covenant' ties it all—special love and mercy for covenant keepers.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's modern convergence. Pioneer sacrifices mirrored ancient covenants, now ours in daily discipleship.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Notice the typology: lamb's blood on doorposts saves firstborn, Christ's blood saves us eternally. Cultural insight—Passover lamb without blemish, inspected publicly, just as Christ was.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Archaeological echoes make it real. Brass serpent on pole—ancient healing symbols, but Christ elevates it to faith in Him.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, Numbers 21's context: Israelites murmuring, bitten by serpents, healed by looking. Parallels sin's bite, looking to cross.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Jonah's three days in the fish—resurrection type, tied to Nineveh's repentance. Cross-reference web is stunning.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And manna gathered daily teaches reliance on Jehovah daily, like manna from heaven.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: These connections change everything. How do we teach this pattern to others?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Start with questions like our hook. Use visuals: pictures of Isaiah foretelling Christ. Sing 'Seek the Lord Early' or 'When I Am Baptized' for covenants.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Perfect for families. Now, generational mapping—from Adam learning sacrifices, to Abraham's altar, Moses' tabernacle.

script.speaker: David
script.text: To Christ's temple body, restoration temples. Each dispensation builds the same covenant path home.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: JST restores Adam's full understanding, linking sacrifices to Christ explicitly.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Moses 5 shows it. Plain and precious indeed.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: What about Melchizedek? JST Genesis 14 shows his city of Salem becoming Zion.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Order of Melchizedek priesthood, high priesthood after Son of God. Echoes Enoch, prepares for Christ's.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Priesthood pattern across dispensations. This is scriptural detective work at its best.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, here's a deeper layer: Exodus 6:3's JST footnote reveals God as Jehovah from the beginning, but manifest progressively.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Resolves apparent contradictions. Modern prophets like Oaks confirm it.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, 'hear Him' from the Father points to Jehovah's words as Christ's.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Applying today: as we study Old Testament, watch for covenants making us peculiar treasure.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Jeremiah 31 promises inward law, fulfilled in baptism, sacrament, temple.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: President Nelson teaches covenants bring mercy amid trials, like ancient saints.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Family joy, discord, faith—universal, pointing to Savior.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Despite intimidating ancient culture, familiar gospel themes emerge.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Enoch wept for worlds, but rejoiced in Zion—hope amid destruction.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Abraham's council shows premortal us choosing covenants.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: This hooks me for the year. Listeners, notice Jehovah everywhere.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Look for symbols, covenants, His voice. Transform your study.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Thanks, David. Dive into the Old Testament this week—find Christ as Jehovah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Until next time, keep seeking those plain and precious truths.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: See you soon on the Come Follow Me Podcast.
